column2: alternatively Los Baños (lohss BAN-yohss) with the tilde on the ñ
column3: is a city in Merced County
column4: central California. It is located in the San Joaquin Valley
column5: near the junction of State Route 152 and Interstate 5.

column2: 972 at the 2010 census
column4: 869 at the 2000 census. The city is served by Los Banos Municipal Airport for air transport access.

column1: The town's Spanish name Los Baños means "the baths".; it is named after a spring that feeds natural wetlands in the western San Joaquín Valley.  Its official spelling
column2: reflected in the name of its post office
column3: omits the tilde of the ñ
column4: though some signs in town show its name as Los Baños.

column1: Los Banos is located on the west side of the San Joaquin Valley
column2: 26 miles (42 km) southwest of Merced
column3: at approximately 118 ft (36 m) elevation. Its coordinates are 37°03′30″N 120°51′00″W. The city is at the intersection of California State Route 152 and California State Route 165. To the west is Interstate 5
column4: which runs north-to-south between the Bay Area and Los Angeles

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 10.1 square miles (26 km2)
column3: of which 10.0 square miles (26 km2) is land and 0.1 square miles (0.26 km2) (1.22%) is water.

column1: Los Banos sits on the southwestern edge of extensive national and state game refuges; wetlands that support waterfowl and other wildlife habitat along a stretch of the San Joaquin river that still carries water and the Grasslands Ecological Area
column2: home to rare California Grasslands habitat. The San Luis National Wildlife Refuge Complex includes San Luis National Wildlife Refuge which includes the Kesterson Unit
column4: West Bear Creek and the Blue Goose Unit. Nearby are the Merced National Wildlife Refuge and the San Joaquin River National Wildlife Refuge. Fishers
column6: birdwatchers and other recreational users flock to Los Banos year round.

column1: Los Banos has a Mediterranean climate with cool winters and hot summers. Most of the precipitation falls in the winter months. Gusty winds are common in the late afternoon
column2: especially in the vicinity of nearby Pacheco Pass.

column1: There is an average of 96.9 days with highs of 90 °F (32 °C) or higher
column2: and an average of 29.4 days with lows of 32 °F (0 °C) or lower. The record high temperature of 116 °F (47 °C) was on July 25
column3: 1931. A record low temperature of 14 °F (−10 °C) was on January 11

column1: The average annual rainfall is 9.95 inches (25.3 cm). There is an average of 46 days with measurable precipitation. The wettest year recorded was 1998 with 21.08 inches (53.5 cm) and the driest year was 1947 with 4.61 inches (11.7 cm). The most rainfall in one month was 8.08 inches (20.5 cm) in March 1998. The most rainfall in 24 hours was 2.40 inches (6.1 cm) on January 18
column2: 1914. Although snow is rare
column3: 3 in (7.6 cm) fell in January 1916 and 1.5 inches (3.8 cm) fell in January 1962.

column2: Los Banos is in the  12th Senate District
column5: represented by Democrat Adam Gray.In the United States House of Representatives

column1: The Los Banos area was initially settled
column2: according to Mexican land grant records
column3: back in the 1840s. The first white settler in the area was Uriah Wood
column4: who built his two-room cabin in 1859. The original site of Los Banos was located several miles from the current town center
column5: about a mile and half west of the railroad near present-day Volta.  The town was essentially a trading post and received its name when the Post Office was established and the Post Office Department designated the office "Los Banos" after the nearby creek.  When the railroad arrived
column6: Los Banos relocated to its present-day site.

column1: The first post office opened in 1873.Land and water rights were important to early Los Banos residents
column2: but those rights were recognized only when the land and deed were registered.  Sometimes those rights depended on fleet footedness
column3: as it did in the "race" between Los Banos residents Uriah Wood and Henry Miller.  Wood
column4: whose homestead was located off of Badger Flat Road
column5: raced Miller to the land office in Stockton to insure his claim to the land would be recognized.  After crossing the San Joaquin River
column6: Wood paid the ferryman $5 to hold the boat on the east side of the river to insure he would gain sufficient distance from Miller to ensure he would reach the land office first.  Wood succeeded and the seven sections that he registered cost him only 45¢ an acre.The centerpiece of downtown Los Banos is Henry Miller Plaza
column8: Henry Miller. The 10-acre (4.0 ha) half-oval public plaza features a monumental scale bronze arrangement of Miller with cattle. At one time in the late nineteenth century
column9: Miller was the largest land owner in the United States. The success of his business monopolized the California agricultural industry
column10: funneling resources and supplies to create his prosperous company. Centered around cattle farming
column11: the Miller and Lux Corporation ultimately transformed the San Joaquin Valley into what can be considered as a precursor to corporate farming and turning independent farmers into wageworkers. His company
column13: was headquartered in Los Banos on a site currently housing the Mexican restaurant España's and the Canal Farm Inn.

column1: Los Banos has a long history of Portuguese and Spanish immigrants
column2: as do many of the nearby towns on the west side of the San Joaquin Valley. This is reflected both in local restaurants and in several festivals and parades that take place during the year. There is also a significant community of Basques. Los Banos is locally known for its annual May Day Fair during the first week of May.

column1: Los Banos is home to The Randall Fawcett House which is a Frank Lloyd Wright designed Usonian home.A member of the Manson family
column2: Susan Atkins attended Los Banos High School
the city's population has changed with a continuing influx of people who work in the San Jose/Silicon Valley area but seek more affordable housing and slower pace of  semi-rural life
column3: a pattern seen in many other small towns within commuting distance of Silicon Valley.

column1: K–12 education is provided by the Los Banos Unified School District. In addition
column2: the Los Banos Campus of Merced College has served community college students since 2007.
